prevents me from coming to any certain conclusion whether the small
inner portion is here the older, the large outer portion having grown
in the first instance from its margin <u>a a</u>, and having gradually
extended itself around it; or whether the outer portion is the
residue of an unusually eccentric disk, which, having lost its
nucleus<s>,</s> and the zones immediately surrounding it, has
filled up the central space with an extension from its innermost
zone, which is consequently the newest portion of the whole. _
<s>40</s> It is interesting to find evidence in <u>fossil</u> specimens, that
the same kind of reparation has taken place. In a fragment of an
Orbitolite from the Calcaire grossier of Paris, represented in Fig 3
under a low magnifying power for the sake of including the entire
specimen, there has obviously been a similar outgrowth from the
zones formed from the uninjured margin, along the fractured
edge, tending to restore the fragment to its typical symmetry.

41  This series of abnormal phenomena, then, not only confirms
the conclusion<s>s</s> that seemed fairly deducible from our previous
examination of the normal mode of growth, with regard to the
